div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, April 6, 1890
div1.opener:
C1
B22
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798 * U. S. * 1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of US. Gulf Quarantine, Surgeon's Office.
April 6/90
My Dear Mother:
div1.p:
It is Easter Sunday just at night-
My barges came back last night & are now lying
outside of the bar & I will bring them in tomorrow.
A great thing is water transportation- Three men (that would
do) will bring a little over a mile the two flats
with 10 cords of wood & 10,000 f't of lumber it
will be less than 4 hours work; about 12.4 horse waggonloads
& if we have worst wind they will come of themselves.
Glad am I to get them back, we have been idling
here for three weeks waiting for them, with an abun-
dance of work to do. The weather has cut me out of 8 days.
Little Ed isn't well the past three days - a bad kind of
diarrhea - although not a violent one. The others are
all well- Laura is pretty well over her grippe,
& although not fully strong is getting so.
We had a rough trip back from Biloxi went over
before diseases - & for the 1st time this winter had to
stop for harbor, but stopped only one hour.
I don't get sea sick but the travelling
doesn't suit me. I am always tired &
confused the next day & yet while afloat
I am all right no matter how rough provided
we are under way.

I do not expect to go ashore more than once more before the
season opens - although I will probably spend two days at ship
Island on the next trip of the sloop

Taken all things together I believe I will be glad when Q. begins
I expect less work, but considerably more bother, especially about
the beginning, than usual. I am expecting to hear from
the steamer proposed to be furnished, but as things are here I had
just as soon for her to stay away as to come. I will if she comes
have to discharge some of my old - & good - employees, which
is always a painful thing to do.

I will be able to pay the $400.00 by June 1st (or as soon thereafter
as the May cheques came in) & will be very glad to get it done.
The big freezes of March 2 & 16 seem to have been severe in
Fla. What they did to me I have not heard, but seem to have
been very hard on the vegetables - especially tomatoes & early
sweet potatoes & water melons. Everything was full of young
growth. It was colder in Jacksonsville than in Norfolk
& reached 24° all around N.O. & Mobile. Mr. Hendrix is
a man to whom correspondence comes hard & while I don't suppose
any damage is done we cannot draw as favorable an Angu-
ry from his not writing as if he were a readers writer
the only risk is to the young trees & to the blows for this years
crop & I rather expect that the young trees were not set
out waiting for a rain - it has been a very dry year &
so that little or no harm is done. The grown orange tree is tough, when
anywhere near dormant, but the young one is for more tender, & a new
planted are should
be very easily nipped.
However I will hear if any harm is done next week. The old trees I know
are all right - although
a short crop
is probably
for one
year.

Rec' a letter from Mr. MD saying that Emma would start about April 1st & asking
when I could return the $400. Maybe I can by the early part of May, but by June I
am certain.
